Comment: First, the legal term is "dangerous **and** unusual", not "dangerous **or** unusual".  Every weapon is "dangerous" when used.  In the same manner, a car, screwdriver, or stove is also dangerous.  As to unusual, there are two problems there.  First, what is unusual?  Because of the "sporting purposes"^1 ban from 1968, coupled with the 1986 freeze on registering new weapons, there is an artificial scarcity on Registrable automatic firearms.  In addition, these firearms are slowly breaking down and wearing out.  I've never seen any official count on registered automatics, but some of the higher estimates I've seen put the number at a quarter million.  Or about one machine gun for every fourteen hundred people.  Is that unusual?  I think so.  But I also think that it is unnatural.  Scarcity by fiat, not by running out of the basic materials.  The other problem with banning or restricting unusual weapons, is it stifles progress.  Take, for instance, the California handgun roster.  As I understand (not being from there), you can only buy from a dealer a weapon on that list.^2 What this has done is to ban the sale of newer versions of handguns, where safety and ergonomic concerns have been addressed.  Imagine if a state put a freeze on cars made after 1985.  That would mean you couldn't buy a car with a third brake light, anti-lock braking, airbags, backup cameras, or a glow-in-the-dark trunk latch.  The idea of not being able to buy a car with such safety implementations isn't ridiculous. It's not even Ludacris. Such an idea is Plaid.  How is restricting the same in a handgun any less idiotic?   1. Defined by the ATF as hunting and target shooting only  2. My understanding is there is a loophole that allows LEOs to sell personal weapons to civilians that are not on the roster.
